Hi Mattias and Everyone,

I joined the list several months ago and experimented a bit with JNEAT. 
I too have an interest in using NEAT to develop a trading system, or at 
least a very special indicator.

Shortly after I discovered NEAT I also realized my search for 
appropriate inputs was a bit like flailing around in the dark. I needed 
access to an expert in the domain or I needed to greatly increase my 
knowledge of the domain. To that end I opened a free game account with 
a currency trading platform and began experimenting with a few existing 
manual trading systems. I'm not yet ready to start coding again (or to 
start trading with real money!) but I can share my thoughts to date. 
Anyone familiar with Dr. Elders' books on trading will notice the 
influence.

The trading systems I'm interested in have a setup and trigger. Where 
the setup is a specific set of market conditions that may lead to the 
trigger. The trigger is the actual flag to enter the trade. The idea is 
to filter the historical data to use only test cases that match a 
specific setup. Depending on the rules of the trading system, the setup 
may only occur most often during a trending phase or it could be a 
setup that targets swings during a sideways or consolidation phase. I 
think either can be profitable but might be best approached as 
different systems. In any event, the goal is to evolve a network(s) to 
give a confidence measure based on the trigger occurring after a 
specific setup. Any trading system, good or otherwise will having 
losing trades. I'll be perfectly happy If I can take a good system and 
filter out some losing trades without throwing out too many nice ones.

The trading systems I'm working with are price action and standard 
indictor based and involve two timeframes. The trading timeframe and a 
timeframe 5 orders of magnitude greater. If the trading timeframe is 
based on daily data, the longer timeframe would be based on weekly 
data. The inputs would be the indicator(s) from each timeframe along 
with the price data for each timeframe. Each training case would be 
data spanning some portion of the setup to the trigger. The target 
output would be 1.0 for the greatest successful result over the 
training set while 0.0 would be the worst result over the training set. 
The result is defined as the difference in price from the entry trigger 
to the exit signal. (or stop loss reached) The training cases would be 
limited to setups that actually result in the trigger occurring as the 
trade would not be entered without the trigger occurring anyway.

A typical trading system might involve two indicators and price (or 
differences) for each timeframe. That could involve a few dozen inputs 
depending how many time steps of the long term timeframe are required. 
Or could this be setup as multiple continuous time steps with a single 
output at the end of the series?

Just my thoughts at this point. This approach might short cut some of 
the more grievous problems of the domain.

I have really enjoyed reading this list over the last several months. 
Thanks much to Ken and everyone involved.

- jim
